awd_titl_txt: Drivers of Selective Mass Extinction: Insight from Integrated Paleontological and Geochemical Records
awd_abstract_narration:
Environmental changes in the modern world threaten many species with extinction. Understanding how similar disruptions drove extinction in Earth's past provides essential context for understanding current risks to the biosphere. This project focuses on the Late Devonian mass extinction, one of the "Big 5" mass extinctions in Earth's history, which occurred approximately 372 million years ago. It will address the following questions: 1) How did environmental conditions change during this extinction? 2) What kinds of animals survived the extinction and what kinds died? 3) What features or traits of these organisms promoted survival versus extinction? The project will combine information from multiple spatial scales, including extensive fossil collections from Late Devonian-aged rocks in upstate New York and Pennsylvania and 'Big data' mined from global, community-wide databases. The project includes outreach through local museums, including public lectures on extinction and the development of new hands-on activities for use at a local children's museum. 

The field-based component of the project will focus on stratigraphic ranges of brachiopod and coral species in the upper Frasnian and lower Famennian of the Appalachian Basin, organic carbon isotopes through measured stratigraphic sections, and proxies for oxygenation, including fossil content and trace metals. The global component will draw on the temporal, paleoenvironmental, and paleolatitudinal ranges of genera in the Paleobiology Database and other databases; new Late Devonian collections will be added to improve data coverage. Leading proposed causes of extinction include global cooling and ocean anoxia. At both the regional and global scales, selectivity of extinction with respect to these factors will be evaluated using latitudinal range as a proxy for temperature tolerance and paleoenvironmental preference (depth preference and range) as a proxy for vulnerability to oxygen depletion.

por.por_cntn:
Studying the causes and effects of ancient mass extinction events can provide important context for understanding current and future threats to biodiversity (e.g., the "Sixth Extinction"). The Frasnian-Famennian mass extinction took place about 372 million years ago, and it consisted of two pulses that coincided with climate cooling and the spread of low-oxygen conditions in many shallow seas and oceans. Here, we examine these two pulses based on extensive fossil collecting in western New York and Pennsylvania, which were covered by a shallow sea at the time of the extinction. We focused on brachiopods, which are filter-feeding invertebrate animals that were common in shallow seas and oceans in the Devonian. Their shells are commonly preserved as fossils in sandstone and mudstone strata in this region. We used a variety of techniques to verify the ages of the rocks and fossils, including measuring stable carbon isotope ratios (the ratio of 13C to 12C), to ensure that we correctly correlated these two pulses with the global record.

 

Our goals were to determine which species went extinct, when they went extinct, and to identify any traits that might have made the victims particularly vulnerable. We detected no correspondence between habitat (e.g., shallow vs. deep water) and extinction risk, but species that were likely adapted to warmer-water conditions did fare worse based on several statistical analyses. This suggests that climate change was probably an important cause of extinction in this fauna. Several lines of evidence, based on both fossil occurrences and geochemistry, suggest that anoxic conditions did not substantially extend into the shallow-water habitats in which these brachiopods lived, so it was unlikely to be the direct cause of extinction.

 

Unlike elsewhere in the world, the first pulse of extinction in New York and Pennsylvania was by far the most destructive, with half of species going extinct; the second pulse was almost non-existent. We suggest that this unusual pattern of extinction might result from the biogeographic setting: the Appalachian seaway was somewhat isolated from other water bodies by geographic barriers and differences in habitat and substrate. Thus, in this region, vulnerable species might have gone extinct during the first pulse because they were unable to migrate to habitable refugia during the mass extinction.

 

We also examined the effects of the extinction on the surviving species of brachiopods. Despite the loss of many co-occurring species, the survivors exhibited niche conservatism, meaning that they occupied the same habitats before and after the extinction, instead of evolving to occupy different environmental conditions. The composition of the brachiopod fauna did change considerably, however, because the victims of the extinction were concentrated in the orders Atrypida and Strophomenida, whereas new species immigrating into the region after the extinction were largely members of the Productida.

 

These results reinforce the connection between climate change and extinction that has been seen elsewhere during mass extinctions, while suggesting that biogeographic setting is also an important factor to consider in evaluating extinction risk on different time scales. These results are being published in a number of journal articles, and we have also shared them with public audiences.
